intro: Gomphia amplexicaulis, commonly known as the clasping gomphia, is a rare and unique plant native to the southern regions of South America. It is a member of the Poaceae family, which includes grasses, and is characterized by its distinctive morphology. The plant features a basal rosette of narrow, grass-like leaves that encircle the stem, giving it its common name. Its inflorescence consists of a single, elongated spikelet that bears tiny, wind-pollinated flowers. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, Gomphia amplexicaulis is considered an endangered species.
